Title: Colony size predicts division of labour in Attine ants.
Journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Keywords:
Division of labour, Formicidae, queen-worker dimorphism,
worker size polymorphism, social evolution
Abstract:
Division of labour is central to the ecological success of
eusocial insects, yet the evolutionary forces driving increases in
complexity are little known. As larger colonies evolve, the evolution of
the division of labour is hypothesised to be driven by the importance of
indirect fitness. However, formal tests of this size-complexity
hypothesis are rare and the influence of environmental factors on
division of labour and colony size remains unclear. Here we show colony
size is positively related to both non-reproductive and reproductive
division of labour using a phylogenetic comparative analysis of social
and environmental traits for 33 species of Attini, a diverse tribe of
neotropical ants. Environmental variation was not found to have a
significant effect on any division of labour measure or colony size.
Unlike previous studies, we separately analysed two components of the
division of labour and reveal that colony size may be acting upon
aspects of social complexity in different ways. Non-reproductive
division of labour may evolve first in response to increasing colony
sizes, which then later impacts reproductive division of labour.
Determining the evolutionary drivers of colony size may help contribute
to the mechanistic understanding of the evolution of social complexity
in eusocial organisms.
